title: 1914 SANS with unusual diamond tail on Q
content:
Hello

Found this lovely old masthead font from an archive image of a French invoice apparently dated 1914...  
 [http://olddesignshop.com/2012/02/free-vintage-image-french-invoice/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150214073102/http:/olddesignshop.com/2012/02/free-vintage-image-french-invoice/ "http://olddesignshop.com/2012/02/free-vintage-image-french-invoice/")

Interesting detail with the diamond 'Q' tail and the relatively squashed bowl on the 'U'...

Any clues or references?

many thanks!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150214073102im_/http:/typophile.com/files/OldDesignShop_FrenchReceiptAug1914_whole_6727.gif)

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [deliQUet\_FrenchReceiptAug1914.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20150214073102/http:/typophile.com/files/deliQUet_FrenchReceiptAug1914.gif) | 6.95 KB |
| [OldDesignShop\_FrenchReceiptAug1914.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20150214073102/http:/typophile.com/files/OldDesignShop_FrenchReceiptAug1914.gif) | 33.52 KB |
author: mvor

comments.content: Seems pretty close to an older sans such as Akzidenz Medium or Monotype Grotesque, except that 'Q'!

Novocento seems to be getting close...

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150214073102im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Screen-Shot-2015-01-30-at-23_4874.04.15.gif)

Looks like engraved letters. Most of the documents of this type from the era were not typeset.  
For a substitute, without the special \_Q\_ think about a squarish sans serif. Perhaps Meta [https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/ff-meta/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150214073102/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/ff-meta/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/ff-meta/")  
Don

The ampersand is the clue here: this is a variation of Copperplate, and as Don said, most likely hand-engraved:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/copperplate-gothic/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150214073102/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/copperplate-gothic/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/copperplate-gothic/")

Widen Engraver’s Gothic a bit, and it might also work (though it has a distinctly different ampersand):  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/paratype/engravers-gothic/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150214073102/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/paratype/engravers-gothic/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/paratype/engravers-gothic/")

Hello and thanks for the clues, I imagine these are indeed some kind of localised engraved letterforms, seems close to a 'sans' version of Copperplate 30 AB, or a slightly condensed Engraver's Gothic...

many thanks

Matt

Copperplate Gothic was designed by Frederic W. Goudy for ATF in 1901. The condensed versions shown in my 1923 ATF type book are a good match for the digital ones now available from Linotype [https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/copperplate-gothic/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150214073102/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/copperplate-gothic/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/copperplate-gothic/")  
I have not checked the earlier ATF books, but I expect that the condensed versions were offered before 1914 and would probably have been a familiar face to the French Engraver.  
Clip the mini serifs and Voilà!  
Don

Here is a little test trimming serifs from Copperplate Gothic 30AB (Adobe) — pretty close, thanks for the tip!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150214073102im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Copperplate30AB-trimmed_5054.gif)
